newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Bass unit in S.Africa gaming machine deal.
newsitem.headline: Bass unit in S.Africa gaming machine deal.

text.p: British brewery group Bass Plc subsidiary Bass Leisure said it had finalised a 250 million rand deal with two South African black business organisations to manufacture and distribute gaming machines by early next year.

"We have reached agreement with two influential partners to build a gaming machine company in Bloemfontein that will provide jobs in manufacturing, management and sales," Bass Leisure South Africa director Roger Withers told a news conference on Wednesday.
"The value of the investment will initially be 100 million rand and the total investment over the next couple of years will be 250 million rand," he said.
The partners are the National African Federated Chamber of Commerce and the Foundation for African and Business Consumer Services. Both will share 49 percent of the holding, Withers said.

Construction of the plant could begin as early as October with production earmarked to start early next year depending on how quickly the government granted the company a licence to manufacture the machines, he said.
The Bloemfontein manufacturing plant would create jobs for about 500 people and the sales office in Gauteng province would create further employment, he said.
Withers warned that if the government imposed a tax of more than 10 percent on the capital generated by the machines it would adversely affect the growth of the business.
"The taxation on gaming machines produces good tax revenue but we need the government to set the rate at a sensible level and not kill the industry before it starts," he said.
Bass Leisure, an international company with an annual turnover of about eight billion rand, is a subsidiary of Bass Plc which is listed on the London and New York stock exchanges.
